com.gluonhq.charm.glisten.application

Class GlassPane

  • java.lang.Object
    • javafx.scene.Node
      • javafx.scene.Parent
        • javafx.scene.layout.Region
          • javafx.scene.layout.Pane
            • javafx.scene.layout.BorderPane
              • com.gluonhq.charm.glisten.layout.MobileLayoutPane
                • com.gluonhq.charm.glisten.application.GlassPane
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javafx.css.Styleable, javafx.event.EventTarget

    public class GlassPane
extends MobileLayoutPane
    The GlassPane exists in an invisible layer above the main UI of a Glisten MobileApplication. It is created by Glisten automatically, and as such there is no publicly available constructor - instead developers who want to interact with the GlassPane are encouraged to call the MobileApplication.getGlassPane() method (via the MobileApplication.getInstance() singleton).

    As mentioned, the GlassPane can be thought of as an invisible layer above the main UI of a Glisten application. Common use cases include using the glass pane as a means to show dialogs and popups.

    In most cases, direct interaction with the GlassPane is unnecessary, as Glisten ships with a number of classes that do the necessary GlassPane manipulation behind the scenes. For example, refer to classes such as SidePopupView and Dialog.

    Since:
    1.0.0
    See Also:
    MobileApplication, SidePopupView, Dialog
